subject: Art
title: Grid Systems
description: Underlying structural frameworks that organize visual layouts.

hook.text: Open any well-designed magazine, website, or poster. Behind the visible layout, there's an invisible grid â€” a system of columns, rows, and margins that organizes everything into a cohesive structure.

buildup.text: A grid divides the canvas into modules: columns (vertical divisions), rows (horizontal divisions), gutters (spaces between), and margins (edges). Elements snap to this grid for alignment and order.

discovery.text: Grids create consistency across multiple pages or pieces. A 12-column grid can be divided into 2, 3, 4, or 6 equal sections â€” incredibly flexible while maintaining visual order.

twist.text: Grids aren't prisons. They're starting points. The best designs establish a grid, then strategically break it to create emphasis. An element that breaks the grid draws attention precisely because everything else follows it.

climax.text: Overlay a 3-column grid on a blank page. Place a headline spanning 2 columns, an image in 1 column, and body text below. Notice how the grid instantly creates professional, organized layouts.

punchline.text: Grids create order. Breaking the grid creates emphasis. Both are design tools.

quiz.question: Why are 12-column grids popular in design?
options: They can be evenly divided into 2, 3, 4, or 6 sections â€” maximum flexibility
